l.2 Λ
Four lines of Greek letters centred on the face of the stone, but with a leftward bias.

Very neatly carved wide, regular letters of a fairly square module, with minimal serifs and all letters of near equal size. Straight bar alpha; epsilon with only slightly shorter middle bar; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes descen half-way; omicron near full size; pi has equal length verticals with slight overhang on both sides of the cross bar; rho has large rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is circular and without over-extended vertical; omega is open and tear-drop shaped.
late second century BCE, or early C1 BCE, following Ampolo and Erdas (previously dated earlier by Nenci) and confirmed by parallel material

Remains of two lines of text preserved, with slightly irregular right margin to the lines.

Regular, deeply incised letters, of which alpha the widest. Borken bar alpha; epsilon has shorter middle bar; Mu has vertical first and last, with middle strokes only descending half-way; omicron is small and mid-line; rho is rounded and closed; sigma is regular four bar, with horizontal top and bottom, middle strokes half-width.
Salinas, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità

Inscription recording works undertaken by the agoranomos Herakleios
Text is set out over three lines, the first two left justified, the third crudely centred, with a vacat both above and below.

The letters are incised somewhat crudely, more in the style of scratched than formally engraved letters, but of roughly equal size throughout. Lunate epsilon and sigma, uncial omega, mu tending towards cursive.
Giustolisi, 1999, Petra: atlante delle antiche strutture rupestri dell'alta valle del Platani (Castronovo)

Parts of two lines preserved, with a wide space between them; unclear if more lines were preserved above.

The letters are somewhat worn, but present a regular and wide/square module, broadly and deeply incised. Alpha with straight bar, epsilon with shorter middle bar, omicron smaller and above the line, rho with a small closed eye.

Honorific for Lucius Iulius Agrippa, euergetes
Four lines centred on the upper half of the plaque.
Slightly irregular letters iwth a broad square module, but narrower towards the end of each line. E has upward curling serifs; triangular interpuncts; final A of line 3 is small, at 29mm.
Suggested to be Tiberian or Claudian on palaeographic and onomastic grounds
Tribulato, 2012, Siculi bilingues? Latin in the inscriptions of early Roman Sicily

Remains of two lines of Latin letters, with a moulding above.

Deeply incised elegant, v-cut letters, with pronounced serifs and comma-shaped interpuncts. The letters are very regularly proportioned and neatly cut, fairly closely spaced, and with faint guidelines top and bottom.
Giustolisi, 1976, Parthenicum e le Aquae Segestanae

1[---]β[---]
Entella 3 = Nakone A: decree of reconciliation

The text fills the face of the tablet. Lines 1-3 are indented by c.2 letters, and line 2 is surely complete and ended with a vacat occupied by the now lost nail hole upper right. Lines 34 and 35 appear compressed (implying the engraver was aware when he began line 34 that the text would run over; the vacat of line 35 is only partial, as line 34 falls towards the lower edge as it proceeds).

The several instances in which the cutter omitted one or more letters and subsequently inserted them above the already engraved text are notable (ll.8, 13, 20, 33); the phenomenon is not to be seen on the other tablets.
First Punic War (264-241 BCE), and commonly attributed to the second half of the war.
Image courtesy of the Centre for the Study of Ancient Documents, Faculty of Classics, University of Oxford
